title: 55% of Brits do not know when Union Jack flown upside down
text: HOW TO WORK IT OUT The key to working out the correct answer is to look at the top corner. When the flag is flown correctly, the thick white bar in the top corner closest to the flagpole should be along the top edge of the flag. There is also a raging debate about the correct name for the British flag. Almost half of Brits believe 'Union Jack' is the only proper name while some suggest that term should be reserved for when the flag is being flown from a ship. About a quarter of Britons say 'Union Flag' is the correct name, according to the survey. However, the document Flying Flags in the United Kingdom, produced by Parliamentâ€™s Flags & Heraldry Committee in conjunction with the Flag Institute, says both names are allowed. Tricky: One third of respondents chose the wrong answer while another 22 per cent said they didn't know which was correct, according to YouGov Some 16 per cent of respondents knew that both terms can accurately be used to refer to the flag. And even those who should know better don't always get it right. In February last year, Brussels bureaucrats were left red-faced after it emerged the Union Jack had been flown upside down outside the European Parliament while PM David Cameron was holding talks inside. In 2012, the flag was raised the wrong way up above the EU Parliament in Strasbourg.
